title: Farmers in flood-hit Maharashtra say recovery may take up to five years
content:
HomeIndia NewsFarmers in flood-hit Maharashtra say recovery may take up to five yearsFarmers across flood-hit districts of Maharashtra are grappling with massive crop losses and soil erosion that threaten their long-term livelihoods. While the state government has announced compensation and sought central assistance, many fear that relief measures may be delayed or insufficient to help them rebuild their farms and recover from the devastation.Torrential rains and severe flooding have left a trail of destruction across Maharashtra, with 31 out of the state’s 36 districts reeling under water. The floods have damaged crops spread over more than 50 lakh hectares, devastating the livelihoods of thousands of farmers who now fear a long and uncertain road to recovery.

Crops such as cotton, soybean, oranges, pomegranate, maize, bajra, pulses, and onion have been hit the hardest. Many farmers say their fields have been rendered infertile due to soil erosion and the deposition of stones carried by the floodwaters.

“Soybean’s cost of production is ₹50,000 per hectare. Had the rains not destroyed my crops, I would have earned at least ₹2 lakh,” said Rajendra Akolkar, a farmer from Ahilyanagar district, whose fields were submerged during the torrential downpour.

The Maharashtra government has said that crops across 31 districts have suffered extensive damage and that it has sanctioned compensation of over ₹2,000 crore for more than 31 lakh affected farmers. However, farmers in some of the worst-hit regions told CNBC-TV18 that the losses go far beyond crop destruction, with long-term impacts on soil fertility and productivity. “It will take us four to five years to recover,” said another farmer from Karanji village.

While the state government maintains that the situation continues to remain grim, it has sought assistance from the Centre under the National Disaster Response Fund (NDRF) quota. The opposition and farmer groups, however, are demanding that the government declare this a ‘wet drought’ year to ensure larger financial relief and policy support.

The state has initiated surveys to assess the extent of damage and determine the compensation to be paid, but the opposition alleges that the government is failing to act decisively. Meanwhile, many farmers fear that the aid, even if sanctioned, may be delayed or inadequate.

With farmlands still waterlogged and crops destroyed, Maharashtra’s agrarian economy faces a major setback. For many farmers, rebuilding their livelihoods and restoring their fields to productivity may take years—a recovery that, as they say, “won’t be easy or quick.”

title: Darjeeling landslides: Roads blocked, hundreds stranded – take a look at the devastation
content: Heavy rains triggered deadly landslides across Darjeeling and nearby areas on Sunday, leaving several dead, roads blocked, and hundreds of tourists stranded. Take a look at the devastation and the ongoing rescue efforts.1 / 9Over 20 Dead, Hundreds Stranded | At least 24 people, including children, lost their lives as heavy rainfall triggered massive landslides across Darjeeling and nearby areas on Sunday, October 5, leaving a trail of devastation. North Bengal Development Minister Udayan Guha called the situation “alarming,” while Anit Thapa, chief executive of the Gorkhaland Territorial Administration, said landslides occurred at 35 locations in the picturesque “Queen of the Hills.” (Image: PTI)2 / 9Worst-Hit Areas | According to the National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) and local authorities, fatalities were reported from multiple locations, including Mirik Basti, Sarsaly, Jasbirgaon, Dhar Gaon, the Mirik Lake area, and Nagrakata in Jalpaiguri district. Mirik was the worst-hit, with 11 deaths, while Darjeeling subdivision reported seven, and Nagrakata saw five fatalities. (Image: PTI)3 / 9Roads and Infrastructure Severely Damaged | Homes were swept away, and key roads, including the Mirik–Sukhiapokhri route, remain blocked. An iron bridge connecting Siliguri to Darjeeling was damaged, further isolating the area. (Image: PTI)4 / 9Tourists Trapped Amid Chaos | Hundreds of tourists from Kolkata, Howrah, and Hooghly visiting the region during the festive season were stranded, with families forced to stay indoors amid continuous downpours. (Image: PTI)5 / 9Rescue Operations Underway | Rescue teams, including the Indian Army and NDRF personnel, worked tirelessly to clear debris and locate missing individuals. Temporary relief camps have been established for affected families. (Image: PTI)6 / 9Government Response | West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee held a high-level meeting, opened a 24/7 control room, and announced compensation for victims. She also assured that arrangements would be made to safely evacuate stranded tourists. Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed condolences and said the situation was being closely monitored. (Image: PTI)7 / 9Alarming Rainfall Levels | Banerjee said more than 300 mm of rainfall was recorded in 12 hours, causing severe flooding and landslides. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued alerts for extremely heavy rainfall in sub-Himalayan West Bengal, including Darjeeling and Kalimpong, until October 6, warning of further landslides and road disruptions. A red alert has been issued for Cooch Behar and Jalpaiguri districts, while Darjeeling faces an orange alert. (Image: PTI)8 / 9Long-Term Causes | Experts and environmentalists have warned that human activities, including deforestation, unplanned construction, and poor drainage systems, have made Darjeeling’s fragile slopes highly vulnerable to landslides. They urged stricter enforcement of construction norms, climate-sensitive development, and decentralised disaster planning to prevent such tragedies in the future. (Image: PTI)9 / 9Historical Echoes | Sunday’s disaster echoes past tragedies, including the deadly 1968 deluge that killed nearly 1,000 people, highlighting the ongoing vulnerability of the region to extreme weather events intensified by climate change. Officials described the disaster as the worst since the 2015 landslides that killed nearly 40 people in the region. (Image: PTI)

title: Supreme Court rejects former-Tamil Nadu minister Senthil Balaji plea seeking clarification of earlier order
content:
HomeIndia NewsSupreme Court rejects former Tamil Nadu minister Senthil Balaji's plea seeking clarification of earlier orderSolicitor General Tushar Mehta, appearing for the Enforcement Directorate, questioned the timing of the application and said that it was not in good taste. Read on:The Supreme Court on Monday (Oct 6) refused to entertain a plea of DMK leader V Senthil Balaji seeking clarification of court's earlier order on whether he can be appointed as a minister again during the pendency of trial in alleged cash-for-job scam.

A bench of Justices Surya Kant and Joymalya Bagchi rejected the contention of Balaji, put forth by senior advocate Kapil Sibal representing him, that this court has never said anything about his ministership.

"We don't read the order or cannot read the order as an injunction on you in becoming a minister. However, if the atmosphere of the state is impacted by your becoming a minister or holding a post of power, then we have to ensure that the scheme of justice prevails," the bench said.

Sibal said there was not a word in the April 28 order about Balaji becoming a minister and there can't be any injunction by the court on his becoming a minister while he is being prosecuted.

Justice Kant questioned Sibal as to why the application for clarification was filed after apex court judge Justice Abhay S Oka, who asked him to resign as minister in Tamil Nadu government, has retired.

Read more: Bihar Election Date 2025 Live Updates

Solicitor General Tushar Mehta, appearing for the Enforcement Directorate, also questioned the timing of the application and said that it was not in good taste.

Justice Kant told Sibal, "This court has not prevented you from taking over the post of the minister and it can't prevent you. But after it was found that on becoming minister just days after being granted bail, you were exercising some influence in the trial of cases, the court said it is better you go to jail".

Sibal pointed out that maybe this was in the court's mind but it was not reflected from the order and hence this application was filed.

Justice Bagchi said there were allegations of influence and the court found that these were prima facie correct.

Both Mehta and senior advocate Gopal Sankaranarayanan, appearing for the victims of the scam, took the bench through sequence of orders passed in the matter and said that the court on April 23 gave an ultimatum to Balaji and asked him to make a choice "between post and freedom" as it warned him of cancelling bail if he did not step down as minister.

Sensing the mood of the court, Sibal sought permission to withdraw the plea.

The bench allowed him to withdraw the plea seeking clarification.

In another matter related to Balaji, where victims have approached the court seeking appointment of a special public prosecutor, the bench asked the Tamil Nadu government why these cash-for-job scam cases involving the former minister and state officials be not transferred to Delhi or some other neutral place.
Read more: Cough syrup killing children: Maharashtra, Telangana flag Coldrif batches after deaths in MP, Rajasthan

Senior advocates Abhishek Singhvi and Amit Anand Tiwari, appearing for the Tamil Nadu government, opposed the suggestion of the court saying that it will be a reflection on state judiciary that nothing is being done in these cases.

"We are only giving a suggestion that why not transfer the trial to Delhi or to some other neutral ground because the investigation is complete and only trial remains. The witnesses can depose virtually, if required. This is the court's suggestion because whenever a high state functionary or a minister is involved in criminal cases, allegations of influence or delay in trial are bound to be made," the bench said.

Singhvi and Tiwari sought time to file their response on the issue saying the response of the accused needs to be seen on the issue of transfer of trial outside the state.

Sankaranarayanan submitted that when a former chief minister of the state was involved in a criminal case, the trial was shifted to Karnataka and the court can think on that line also.

The bench said it will look into it and took on record a chart of leading lawyers submitted by Sankaranarayanan for being appointed as special public prosecutors.

It also asked the state government counsels to submit some names who can be appointed as special public prosecutors.

The top court was hearing a petition filed by Y Balaji, challenging the March 28 Madras High Court order dismissing pleas against the clubbing of multiple chargesheets in cases related to the alleged scam.

On July 30, terming the trial involving Balaji a "rudderless ship", the top court said a cricket stadium will be needed to conduct prosecution in the cash-for-job scam related cases where over 2,000 people have been implicated as accused.

Read more: Bihar elections: Voting in two phases on Nov 6 and 11, result on Nov 14, announces EC

It had pulled up the Tamil Nadu government for implicating so many persons as accused, questioned whether they are victims or victimisers and asked for the details of the accused and witnesses.

The top court had said it appears to be the most populated trial of India with 2,000 accused and 500 witnesses and that a small courtroom would not suffice.

Balaji resigned from the M K Stalin-led state Cabinet on April 27 after being pulled up by the top court.

On April 23, the apex court took exception to the fact that Balaji was reinstated as a minister, days after he obtained bail in a money laundering case related to the alleged cash-for-jobs scam.

On September 26, 2024, the top court granted bail to Balaji in a case probed by the Enforcement Directorate.

With Balaji spending more than 15 months in jail, the top court had observed that there was no possibility that the trial would be concluded in the near future.

title: Bihar Elections 2025: 'Mother of all apps' ECINET to streamline these 40 services before Bihar elections
content:
HomeIndia NewsPolitics News'Mother of all apps' ECINET to streamline these 40 services before Bihar Elections 2025The ECINET will also help in resolving the grievances of voters. All contact details, including those of booth level officers (BLOs), will be available on the app.(Photo Credit : The Election Commission's ECINET App )The Chief Election Commissioner of India Gyanesh Kumar on Monday, October 6, announced the implementation of the ECINET app, terming it as the "mother of all apps" which is going to streamline over 40 web and mobile based services provided by the Election Commission.

"About 40 different apps have been created by the Election Commission throughout the years gradually," Kumar said at a conference in New Delhi, where he announced the Bihar polls schedule, which will see voting on November 6 and 11 and the counting will be done on Nov 14.

"So, to combine these together in one place, because every voter or a stakeholder cannot download the different 40 apps, we aimed for ECINET - the mother of all apps. Almost all the apps and services have been combined in the app now. And its progressive implementation as the 'one-stop digital platform' will begin from Bihar elections," he added.

Many different services such as information on voter turnout, voter helpline, election planning, voter services, as well as voting results will be combined in the app.

Read more: Bihar Election Date 2025 Live Updates

Many important services such as the real-time voter turnout updates, will be available on app. The presiding officers will now upload turnout data on ECINET App every two hours on the polling day in order to reduce the time lag in the updating of approximate polling trends, according to the Election Commission.

The digital index cards and reports will also be made available on the app after a few days on the app and the website of the Election Commission.

The ECINET will also help in the resolution of grievances of voters. All the contact details, including those of booth level officers (BLOs), will be available on the app.

The supposed "user-friendly" app will now combine various services and apps such as the Voter Helpline App, Voter Turnout App, cVIGIL, Suvidha 2.0, ESMS, Saksham and KYC App (Know Your Candidate) which together have over 5.5 crore downloads, will now be available on a single platform.

Read more: Bihar elections: Voting in two phases on Nov 6 and 11, result on Nov 14, announces EC

The Commission, in a statement released on May 4, 2025, had said that the data provided through ECINET will be strictly aligned within the legal framework established by the Representation of People Act 1950, 1951, Registration of Electoral Rules, 1960 Conduct of Election Rules, 1961 and instructions issued by ECI from time to time.

title: Watch: Uttarakhand's Kedarnath temple gets 'magical' snowfall
content:
The holy shrine of Kedarnath witnessed a fresh spell of snowfall on Monday, blanketing the temple premises and surrounding areas in a pristine white layer.Uttarakhand experienced a significant weather shift on Monday, October 6, with several regions receiving snowfall and rain, leading to a temperature drop across the state. This weather shift was triggered by an intense Western Disturbance impacting northern India.

The holy shrine of Kedarnath witnessed a fresh spell of snowfall on Monday, blanketing the temple premises and surrounding areas in a pristine white layer. The sudden change in weather created a picturesque sight as thousands of devotees continued to arrive to offer prayers despite the cold and slippery conditions.

Visuals released by the news agency ANI showed the centuries-old stone temple dusted with snow, while pilgrims, wrapped in raincoats and woollens, gathered in large numbers to witness the divine spectacle.

Watch the video here:
#WATCH | Uttarakhand's Kedarnath temple receives snowfall
Video source: Kedarnath temple committee pic.twitter.com/NgX1lw55f2

— ANI (@ANI) October 6, 2025

Several users shared the beautiful video on X, which featured the Kedarnath Temple draped in white. A user wrote, “Kedarnath Dham, nestled in the Himalayas, receives its first snowfall of the season, blanketing the sacred shrine in white serenity.”
❄️ Winter has arrived in Devbhoomi!
Kedarnath Dham, nestled in the Himalayas, receives its first snowfall of the season, blanketing the sacred shrine in white serenity.????️
???? Watch the first video of this magical moment!#Kedarnath #Rudraprayag #Snowfall #Uttarakhand #WinterVibes pic.twitter.com/vEZuNQEVrl
— Franklin Nigam (@FranklinNigam) October 6, 2025

“Amazing view of snowfall in Kedarnath Dham...Jai Baba Kedarnath... Har Har Mahadev,’’ another posted.
केदारनाथ धाम में बर्फबारी का अद्भुत दृश्य..
जय बाबा केदारनाथ...हर हर महादेव ???????? pic.twitter.com/SRIxts02VQ

— Amrendra Bahubali ???????? (@TheBahubali_IND) October 6, 2025

Located at an altitude of around 11,755 feet, Kedarnath often experiences early snowfall as temperatures start to dip sharply in October. The region’s weather has remained unpredictable over the past few days, with intermittent rain and snow reported in various parts of the state.

In its latest bulletin, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) predicted heavy rainfall and isolated hailstorms in Uttarakhand on October 6 and 7.

The Met Office issued an orange alert for the state, predicting heavy rains on Monday and Tuesday. In addition to the heavy rains, isolated hailstorm activity is also predicted to occur over Uttarakhand on October 6.

Officials stated on Sunday that trekking activities in Chamoli district will be banned for the next two days due to rain and snowfall projections in Uttarakhand's high-altitude areas.

The Chamoli District Disaster Management Office has instructed the Tourism and Forest Departments to halt trekking operations on October 6 and 7.(Edited by : Sudarsanan Mani)First Published: Oct 6, 2025 5:43 PM IST

title: Gadkari says farmers earn ₹45,000 crore from ethanol production
content:
HomeIndia NewsGadkari says farmers earn ₹45,000 crore from ethanol productionUnion Minister Nitin Gadkari said farmers earned ₹45,000 crore from ethanol and EV prices in India will reach parity with petrol vehicles within 4-6 months.Union Road Transport and Highways Minister Nitin Gadkari on Monday highlighted the economic benefits of ethanol production, stating that farmers have earned an additional ₹45,000 crore by producing ethanol from corn.

Speaking at the 20th FICCI Higher Education Summit 2025, Gadkari also projected that the prices of electric vehicles (EVs) in India will reach parity with petrol-powered vehicles within the next four to six months.

"Within the next 4-6 months, the cost of electric vehicles will be equivalent to the cost of petrol vehicles," he said.

The minister emphasised the importance of reducing India’s reliance on fossil fuels, noting that ₹22 lakh crore is spent annually on fuel imports, which he described as both an economic burden and an environmental hazard.

Looking ahead, Gadkari plans for the Indian automobile industry and said, "Within five years, our target is to make India's automobile industry the number 1 in the world."

He added, "When I took charge as transport minister, the size of the Indian automobile industry was ₹14 lakh crore. The size of the Indian automobile industry now is ₹22 lakh crore."

For context, the current size of the US automobile industry is ₹78 lakh crore, followed by China at ₹47 lakh crore, and India at ₹22 lakh crore.

(With inputs from PTI)(Edited by : Vivek Dubey)

title: HPCL adds 5,350 EV chargers to Kazam app to expand charging access nationwide
content:
HomeAuto NewsHPCL adds 5,350 EV chargers to Kazam app to expand charging access nationwideKazam has partnered with Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Ltd (HPCL) to integrate 5,350 EV chargers, including 3,043 DC fast chargers, into its app, expanding charging access across India.Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Ltd. (HPCL), on Monday, added 5,350 of its electric vehicle (EV) chargers, including 3,043 DC fast chargers, to the Kazam app under a new partnership with EV solutions provider Kazam.

The integration uses Kazam’s Open Charge Point Interface (OCPI) platform, giving EV users real-time access to HPCL’s growing charging network across India. The company claims that EV drivers can now locate, navigate, and charge at HPCL stations directly through the app.
HPCL operates more than 24,000 fuel retail outlets and is expanding its EV charging infrastructure under the Government of India’s PM eDrive scheme. The company said the collaboration will support its goal of enabling cleaner mobility and strengthening the country’s EV ecosystem.

“Kazam’s OCPI platform will provide seamless visibility of HPCL chargers, making it easier for users to charge at our stations,” said Paras Shah, COO of Kazam.

“Through this partnership, we aim to offer reliable access to EV charging while supporting the government’s clean transport goals,” said Kushal Kumar Banerjee, Chief General Manager at HPCL.

The Kazam platform enables real-time monitoring for charge point operators (CPOs) and e-mobility service providers (eMSPs), helping maintain network reliability and scalability.

title: TVS Raider 125 launched with boost mode, dual disc brakes and new tech
content:
HomeAuto NewsTVS Raider 125 launched with boost mode, dual disc brakes and new techTVS Motor has launched the new Raider 125 in India with first-in-segment boost mode, dual disc brakes with ABS and glide through technology, priced from ₹93,800 (ex-showroom, Delhi).TVS Motor Company, on Monday, launched the most advanced version of its 125cc motorcycle, the TVS Raider, introducing three segment-first features — Boost Mode with iGO Assist, Dual Disc Brakes with ABS, and Glide Through Technology (GTT).

The Raider is powered by a refined 125cc, 3-valve engine that produces 11.75Nm torque at 6,000rpm. With Boost Mode, riders get an instant power surge for quicker acceleration, while GTT enables smooth movement at low speeds without throttle input, improving fuel efficiency and city usability.

For braking safety, TVS has equipped the Raider with segment-first Dual Disc Brakes and single-channel ABS. The motorcycle also comes with wider tyres — 90/90-17 at the front and 110/80-17 at the rear — designed to offer better grip and handling across different road conditions.

Another key addition is the Follow Me Headlamp function, which keeps the headlamp switched on for a short duration after the engine and ignition are turned off. This feature allows riders to safely navigate dimly lit areas or parking zones.

Riders can choose between two display options: a TFT cluster with over 99 features or a reverse LCD with more than 85 features. Both are powered by TVS SmartXonnect, offering Bluetooth connectivity, voice assist, turn-by-turn navigation, call handling, and notification management.

Styling updates include a metallic silver finish paired with sporty red alloy wheels.

The new TVS Raider is priced at ₹95,600 for the TFT Dual Disc variant and ₹93,800 for the SXC Dual Disc variant (ex-showroom, Delhi). It is now available across all TVS Motor dealerships.

title: Cough syrup killing children: Maharashtra, Telangana flag Coldrif batches after deaths in MP, Rajasthan
content:
HomeIndia NewsHealthcare NewsCough syrup killing children: Maharashtra, Telangana flag Coldrif batches after deaths in MP, RajasthanOn Oct 2, the Tamil Nadu drug control authorities in their report flagged adulterations and declared the Coldrif syrup sample (Batch No SR-13, Mfg: May 2025; Exp: April 2027) manufactured as adulterated.Various states across India, such as Maharashtra, Telangana and Karnataka, have ramped up precautionary actions to stop the consumption and supply of Coldrif cough syrup following the deaths of children reported in Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan.

The Maharashtra Food and Drug Administration on Monday, October 6, appealed to the people to stop the sale or use of Coldrif syrup from the specific batch identified by the Tamil Nadu authorities as "injurious."

"The public is urged to remain cautious and to report any possession of Coldrif Syrup Batch No. SR-13 to the nearest Drugs Control Authority without delay," the Maharashtra FDA said in a statement, as per news agency PTI.

The agency warned that the batch is suspected to be adulterated with diethylene glycol, a chemical that could be toxic to health.

FDA officials are also working towards tracing the distribution of the said Coldrif batch in Maharashtra and have asked the concerned retailers or wholesalers to "freeze" the stock.

Read more: Bihar Election Date 2025 Live Updates

"All drug inspectors and assistant commissioners have been directed to alert retailers, wholesalers and hospitals to immediately freeze any available stock," the FDA statement read.

Telangana "alerts" public against Coldrif 

The Telangana government also initiated efforts to sensitise and caution people in the state against the use of Coldrif cough syrup.

The Director of Public Health of Telangana wrote to the DM&HOs and directed officials to increase awareness among the people about Coldrif syrup Batch No. SR-13, which was found to be toxic.

The directive stated that people should report to the local drug control authority if they were in possession of the Coldrif drug.

The order also urged the DM&HOs to implement and disseminate the advisory released by the Union Health Ministry's Directorate General of Health Services (DGHS).

Karnataka govt asks officers to maintain vigil 
The Karnataka government also directed all enforcement officers in the state to remain cautious about Coldrif syrups.

"All enforcement officers in the state of Karnataka are instructed to keep a strict vigil on the above drug/batch number and similar combinations from manufacturers," Karnataka’s Food Safety and Drugs Administration said in a circular, as per PTI.

Read more: India to revise CGHS rates from October 13: What may change for hospitals and beneficiaries

"Any stockist, distributor, retailer or government institution found in possession of these products, if any, should draw samples for test and analysis, and initiate necessary action as per the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940," it added.

The "toxic Coldrif" syrup batch 

On October 2, the Tamil Nadu drug control authorities, in their report, flagged adulteration in a batch of the syrup and declared the Coldrif syrup sample (Batch No. SR-13, Mfg: May 2025; Exp: April 2027), manufactured by Sresan Pharmaceuticals, Kancheepuram, as adulterated.

The authorities found that these batches contained diethylene glycol (48.6% w/v), a poisonous substance "which may render the contents injurious to health."

Deaths in Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan 

At least 14 children have died in Madhya Pradesh's Chhindwara district while dozens are reported to be in serious condition.

In Rajasthan, at least three children have died due to alleged consumption of the syrup.

Union Health Ministry's actions 

Observing the seriousness of the issue, the Union Health Ministry convened a high-level meeting on Sunday, Oct 5, with all the states and union territories.

The meeting was under the chairmanship of Union Health Secretary Punya Salila Srivastava to review compliance with drug quality regulations and promote the rational use of cough syrups, especially in pediatric populations.

The ministry underlined the need for all drug manufacturers to comply with the Revised Schedule M and warned that strict action would be taken against violators.

Read more: NSE, Tata Memorial Centre join hands to build India’s largest bone marrow transplant facility(Edited by : Prashanth Perumal)

title: Who is Dhira Chaliha Hazarika, the first Assamese woman pilot to return to skies at 85
content:
HomeIndia NewsWho is Dhira Chaliha Hazarika, the first Assamese woman pilot to return to skies at 85Dhira Chaliha Hazarika is the first female pilot from the state of Assam, India, who earned her Pilot’s A Licence at the age of 21.Although Dhira Chaliha Hazarika's name may not appear in every history book, she is still considered legendary in the eyes of Assamese skies and the dreams of many young women as the first Assamese woman pilot.

At 85, Dhira decided to go to the skies once again, a time when most people slow down.

Anand Mahindra, Chairperson of Mahindra and Mahindra, took to X (formerly Twitter) to commemorate Dhira’s achievement by writing: “She deserves a place in India’s Aviation Hall of Fame simply for being a trailblazer.”

“But for flying again at 85, she belongs in a global Hall of Fame for her courage, her resilience, and her life-affirming spirit,” Mahindra added. He also shared the latest clip of Dhira flying over the picturesque landscapes of Berkshire and the River Thames.
This is Dhira Chaliha Hazarika, the first female pilot from the state of Assam, India.
In 1961, at the age of 21, she earned her Pilot’s A Licence.

And in September 2025, at the age of 85, she returned to the skies, taking the controls of a historic Tiger Moth biplane over the… pic.twitter.com/rpGJPl8Jby

— anand mahindra (@anandmahindra) October 6, 2025

Who is Dhira Chaliha Hazarika?

Dhira Chaliha Hazarika was born in Jorhat in 1940, and her first memories are as expansive as the skies she aspired to traverse. Perhaps the beginning of a lifelong obsession, she would climb trees in her home and watch warplanes over the Burma front.

During a period when women were expected to conform to predefined roles, Dhira was lucky to have a father, Kamaleshwar Chaliha, who supported her in following her dreams. Following her graduation from Guwahati's Handique College, Dhira noticed an advertisement in 1959 that would forever transform her life: the Assam Flying Club offered six fully-funded scholarships for pilot training.
She applied.

Dhira would practise flying in Tiger Moths and the indigenous Pushpak, two-seater propeller aircraft, twice a week. Each flight taught not only technical abilities but also courage, patience, and precision because there were no modern conveniences like sophisticated navigation or dependable radio contact.

Dhira Chaliha became the first female pilot of Assam when she earned her Pilot’s A Licence in April 1961, at the age of 21. Her solo flight was from Borjhar to Tezpur. While she was flying between Guwahati, Tezpur, Jorhat, and Shillong, the people of Azara gathered to watch her land.

Despite the practical challenges she faced—such as difficult terrain and no radio communication—she mainly recalls the excitement.

Dhira had to make some sacrifices along the way. She wanted to become a commercial pilot, but her priorities changed when she married Kamal Hazarika and moved to London. Her decision to put her family before her profession was one that many women in her generation were forced to make.

However, Dhira would continue going to flying clubs in London to tell everyone about her passion for flying.

Over 60 years later, Dhira flew again over England in a Tiger Moth at the age of 85, marking one of the most poignant moments in her life. She flew over Berkshire and the River Thames with Captain John Towell at the controls.

This specific Tiger Moth was not a typical aircraft; it had been in Hollywood productions such as Thunderbirds and The King's Speech.

As the first woman pilot in Assam, Dhira is currently writing her autobiography, which will chronicle her years in the sky.(Edited by : Sudarsanan Mani)

title: University of Western Australia to set up campuses in India
content:
The University of Western Australia will open campuses in Mumbai and Chennai, marking one of the first major foreign university entries into India’s $100-billion higher education market.The University of Western Australia (UWA), one of the Australia's prestigious Group of Eight (Go8) institutions, has announced plans to establish two campuses in India—one in Mumbai and another in Chennai—making it one of the first major foreign universities to enter the Indian higher education market after the government allowed international institutions to set up independent campuses.

Speaking to CNBC-TV18, Professor Guy Littlefair, Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Education and Student Experience) at UWA, said the decision reflects the university’s long-term commitment to India’s rapidly expanding education sector and its potential to become a global hub for higher learning.

“The University of Western Australia is looking at establishing two campuses, one in Mumbai and one in Chennai,” he said. “We absolutely believe we have an opportunity for students in India and from around the region to come to India and have a world-leading qualification.”

Professor Littlefair said India’s location and demographics make it one of the most significant regions for international education growth over the next two decades. “We will have to wait and see how India performs as an international education destination, but it is certainly going to be a hub,” he noted. “Given the policy changes by the University Grants Commission and the government’s decision to welcome foreign universities, we felt this was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.”

He added that UWA’s entry is not a short-term move but part of a broader strategy to build a sustained academic presence in India. “This is not for the short term, we are here for the long term,” he said. “We are looking to develop a comprehensive university offering programs across the arts, humanities, techno-sciences, and health.”

India’s higher education market, estimated at around 100 billion dollars, has become increasingly attractive for global institutions. Professor Littlefair said UWA sees the move as both an academic and economic opportunity. “It is a big market for sure, and one that provides significant stimulus to the economy,” he said.

Explaining the choice of cities, he said Mumbai represents India’s financial heart and has a thriving entrepreneurial ecosystem, making it a natural location for the university’s expansion. Chennai, on the other hand, has a high demand for studies in engineering, computer science and the techno-sciences. “For us, setting up in both cities was an easy decision,” he said.

UWA has already received a letter of intention from the University Grants Commission and is working towards establishing its physical presence in India. Professor Littlefair said the university anticipates opening its doors to students by August next year.

The university is still assessing whether to establish the campuses independently or through a joint venture with an Indian partner. “We are working through whether to set up as a joint venture or on our own. There are pros and cons on both sides,” he said. “Whatever happens, we will be delivering something significant here in India for students who are looking for such opportunities in the future.”

He also assured that the quality of education at the India campuses will match UWA’s standards in Australia. “We have to provide courses offshore to the same standard as those we provide in Australia,” he explained. “There will be some local nuances, but the offerings will be identical in quality.”

UWA will focus strongly on student experience, offering a blend of classroom learning, field work, community engagement and research-based internships. “We focus on the student experience, not just in the classroom but through field work and community engagement,” he said. “We leverage our research expertise and offer internships and work-integrated learning.”

While Professor Littlefair did not disclose the scale of investment, he confirmed that it would be substantial. “Establishing two campuses in a foreign country is a significant investment, but one that is well worth making,” he said. “We see nothing but great opportunity here in India.”

With this move, India’s goal of becoming a global education hub appears to be taking firm shape, as foreign universities begin to translate policy reforms into on-ground partnerships and campuses.

title: Sabarimala gold plating scandal: Kerala HC orders SIT probe; uproar in assembly
content:
HomeIndia NewsSabarimala gold plating scandal: Kerala HC orders SIT probe; uproar in assemblyThe High Court Devaswom Bench has asked the SIT to keep the probe fully private and not reveal any information.The Kerala High Court on Monday, October 6, directed the formation of a Special Investigation Team (SIT) to conduct a probe into the alleged theft of gold from the Sabarimala temple.

Led by former Superintendent of Police S Sasidharan, the investigation will be overseen by Crime Branch chief Additional Director General of Police (ADGP) H Venkatesh and will consist of three inspectors, including cyber experts.

The High Court Devaswom Bench has asked the SIT to keep the probe fully private and not reveal any information. The order dates back to 2019, when the Travancore Devaswom Board (TDB) removed the gold-lined copper plates.

The problem worsened when Unnikrishnan Potty stated that two gold-plated panels presented to the temple in 2019 were stolen from the strongroom, right before the TDB-sponsored Global Ayyappa Sangamam event.

Recently, IDB surveillance discovered the ‘missing’ goods; however, it was claimed that approximately 5 kg of weight was removed from the plates. According to Kerala Devaswom Minister V N Vasavan, the TDB vigilance will submit the report to the High Court on October 8.

Over 5 kg of gold is missing from Sabarimala donations

On Monday, Congress MLA and Leader of Opposition in the Kerala Assembly, VD Satheesan, alleged that over 5 kilograms of gold donated by the UB Group and Vijay Mallya to the temple were misappropriated. He demanded a CBI probe under the supervision of the Kerala High Court.

In a conversation with ANI, he said, “This is a very serious matter... UB Group and Vijay Mallaya donated more than 30 kg of gold to the Sabarimala Temple for plating various things. Unfortunately, through some middlemen, more than 5kg of that gold was robbed.”

Mismatch between old and current gold-plated panels detected

The Devaswom Board Vigilance found that the gold-plated panels on the sanctum are different from the 2019 ones, possibly indicating the loss of panels plated with gold donated by Vijay Mallya, according to a report in Mathrubhumi. This conclusion was drawn from photographic comparisons and supported by a goldsmith's assessment.

The current gold-plated panels at the Sabarimala sanctum sanctorum do not match photographs of the panels from before July 2019. This suggests that the gold panels plated with Vijay Mallya's donated gold in 2019 may have gone missing.

A goldsmith consulted during the inquiry also concluded that the panels are not the same. The vigilance intends to seek High Court permission for forensic tests to definitively determine the age and authenticity of the panels.

Uproar in Kerala Assembly 

Earlier in the day, the Kerala Legislative Assembly witnessed high drama as the Opposition created an uproar over the gold-plating controversy. During the Question Hour, Opposition leader VD Satheesan raised the issue and demanded the resignation of the Devaswom Minister and the Travancore Devaswom Board President.

Opposition MLAs surrounded the Speaker's podium, carrying placards and banners with messages such as “Ayyappan's gold stolen, temple devoured by looters,” obstructing his vision. As the situation became serious, ministers and members of the ruling front stood up from their seats.

Amid the ruckus, Speaker AN Shamseer cancelled Question Hour and momentarily adjourned the House. “Why disrupt the House without even giving a single notice?” he said.

TDB Vigilance records statement of Unnikrishnan Potty

On Sunday, the TDB Vigilance recorded the statement of the former helper and the sponsor of gold-plating works at Sabarimala, Unnikrishnan Potty. He was questioned for nearly three hours at the headquarters in Thiruvananthapuram.

In response to the media's questions, he said, "Don't I have freedom as an individual? Everything will be proven before the High Court. Don't I have the right to move freely? The truth will prevail.”

President Droupadi Murmu to visit Sabarimala temple

President Droupadi Murmu is scheduled to visit the temple on the concluding day of the Thulamasa Pooja on October 22. She is set to be in Kerala for a two-day visit, till October 24, and attend several programmes in the Thiruvananthapuram and Kottayam areas.(Edited by : Sudarsanan Mani)

title: Delhi to witness first 'historic' cloud seeding trial on October 7-9
content:
HomeIndia NewsDelhi to witness first 'historic' cloud seeding trial on October 7-9The operation will be implemented by the Department of Aerospace Engineering at IIT Kanpur, in coordination with experts from the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM), Pune, and the India Meteorological Department (IMD), using a Cessna 206-H aircraft (VT-IIT).Delhi will witness a "historic" first cloud seeding trial on Tuesday, October 7 which is aimed at addressing air pollution in the national capital. This first trial will be carried out in northwest Delhi from October 7 to October 9 as per an MoU signed between the Delhi government and Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kanpur last week. 
The government has secured all necessary permissions to carry out upto five trials with an estimated cost of ₹3.2 crore by November, PTI reported.
Chief Minister Rekha Gupta, during the MoU signing event last week, said that findings from the trial will give more clarity on how to proceed further.
The "MoU paves the way for a two-month cloud seeding trial, which will be carried out on suitable days in October and November using aircraft. The findings will help us decide the way forward. This initiative will prove to be both historic and beneficial for Delhi," the Chief Minister said.

— Press Trust of India (@PTI_News) September 25, 2025

Environment Minister Manjinder Singh Sirsa told PTI that plans for the next five trials will be drawn based on the first seeding trial. "The goal is to quell the smog due to air pollution in Delhi," he said. 
The operation will be implemented by the Department of Aerospace Engineering at IIT Kanpur, in coordination with experts from the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM), Pune, and the India Meteorological Department (IMD), using a Cessna 206-H aircraft (VT-IIT).

title: Namma Metro: Karnataka CM Siddaramaiah proposes renaming it 'Basava Metro'; netizens react
content:
HomeIndia NewsNamma Metro: Karnataka CM Siddaramaiah proposes renaming it 'Basava Metro'; netizens reactOn Sunday, Siddaramaiah recommended renaming the Namma Metro to "Basava Metro" in honour of 12th-century social reformer Basavanna.Bengaluru's famed metro train network may soon witness a significant change as Chief Minister Siddaramaiah announced plans to rename Namma Metro.

On Sunday, Siddaramaiah recommended renaming the Namma Metro to ‘Basava Metro’ in honour of 12th-century social reformer Basavanna. During a public gathering on October 5, the Chief Minister stated that he would forward the proposal to the Central government.

On X, Siddaramaiah stated that if it were a totally state government project, he would have announced it as such right away.

“I will recommend to the central government to name our metro as ‘Basava Metro.’ If this were entirely a state government project, I would have announced it as ‘Basava Metro’ today itself. We have many castes and many religions among us. In the Chaturvarna system, we are placed in the fourth position. Regardless of which caste Shudras belong to, we must realise that we are all one,” he wrote on X.

CM Siddaramaiah further mentioned that he was an admirer of Basavanna, adding, “My belief is that Basava's principles are eternal and relevant--not just in the past, not just today, but forever.”
ನಮ್ಮ ಮೆಟ್ರೋಗೆ "ಬಸವ ಮೆಟ್ರೋ" ಎಂದು ನಾಮಕರಣ ಮಾಡುವ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಕೇಂದ್ರಕ್ಕೆ ಶಿಫಾರಸ್ಸು ಮಾಡುತ್ತೇನೆ. ಇದು ಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿ ರಾಜ್ಯ ಸರ್ಕಾರದ ಯೋಜನೆ ಆಗಿದ್ದರೆ ಇವತ್ತೇ "ಬಸವ ಮೆಟ್ರೋ" ಎಂದು ಘೋಷಿಸಿ ಬಿಡುತ್ತಿದ್ದೆ.
ನಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿ ಅನೇಕ ಜಾತಿ, ಅನೇಕ‌ ಧರ್ಮಗಳಿವೆ. ಚಾತುವರ್ಣ ವ್ಯವಸ್ಥೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ನಾಲ್ಕನೇ ಸ್ಥಾನದಲ್ಲಿ ಇರುವವರು ನಾವು. ಶೂದ್ರರು ಜಾತಿ… pic.twitter.com/k5yUD34UaA

— Siddaramaiah (@siddaramaiah) October 5, 2025

The proposal triggered widespread public discussion, with some Bengalureans arguing that the name was a cherished part of the city's identity and should not be changed.
Many argued that instead of renaming infrastructure projects, the government should prioritise practical issues like expediting under-construction metro lines and reducing peak-hour congestion.

“Our metro's name is nice. If we want to name it after Basavanna, we should name a new station after him,” a user wrote in the comment section.

Another said, “Namma Metro Name is Enough for our Metro. Instead of doing this, focus on developing the city where Basavanna was born.”

“Why didn't you then name your children & and grandchildren to honour Basavanna. Pls stop the appeasement politics. Why can't it be Namma Metro? It's funded by people’s tax, which goes to the State coffers. You haven't paid it from your own pockets,” the third user posted.

“Repair Bengaluru roads first. People are falling and getting hurt. Taking care of citizens should be your top priorities. We are paying huge taxes. Where is going???” a user wrote. “Bengalureans should oppose this. Namma Metro is an iconic name, it should remain as it is,” one user commented.

“First reduce metro ticket prices, then think about renaming it,” another said.

This is not the first time a name change related to Bengaluru's metro has stirred debate. A proposal in September 2025 to rename the Shivajinagar Metro station after St. Mary's caused a political controversy. Announcing the plans, Siddaramaiah stated the state would announce it’s renaming once the central government approves.

At the annual feast of St Mary’s Basilica on September 8, he said, “There is a proposal to name a metro station after St. Mary. Rizwan and I have spoken about it because Rizwan is the MLA of this constituency. I will make a recommendation to the central government.” The announcement had triggered a political storm, with many strongly objecting to the move.(Edited by : Sudarsanan Mani)

title: Mahindra launches 2025 Bolero and Bolero Neo with new design, interiors, and features
content:
HomeAuto NewsMahindra launches 2025 Bolero and Bolero Neo with new design, interiors, and featuresMahindra launches the 2025 Bolero and Bolero Neo in India with refreshed styling, upgraded interiors, new tech features, and new top-end variants priced between ₹7.99 lakh and ₹9.99 lakh.Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd., on Monday, launched the 2025 Mahindra Bolero and Bolero Neo in India. Both models retain their diesel engines and rear-wheel-drive, ladder-frame structure while receiving updated styling, interiors, and features.

The new Bolero starts at ₹7.99 lakh (ex-showroom) for the B4 variant and goes up to ₹9.69 lakh for the top-end B8.  The Bolero Neo starts at ₹8.49 lakh for the N4 and reaches ₹9.99 lakh for the new flagship N11.

New Bolero Classic

The 2025 Bolero continues as a sub-4-meter, rugged SUV with minor cosmetic updates. It features a new grille with chrome inserts, updated fog lamps from the B6 trim onwards, and 16-inch diamond-cut alloy wheels on the B8 variant. A new Stealth Black colour has been added, alongside existing Diamond White, DSAT Silver, and Rocky Beige. 2025 Bolero Classic

Inside, the Bolero now has a 17.8 cm touchscreen infotainment system, steering-mounted audio controls, leatherette upholstery, improved seat cushioning, and USB-A and USB-C charging ports. RideFlo Tech suspension has been updated to improve ride quality and handling. The SUV maintains seating for seven with a foldable third-row seat.

The 1.5-litre three-cylinder diesel engine produces 76 hp and 210 Nm of torque and is paired with a 5-speed manual gearbox. ABS, dual airbags, and reverse parking sensors are standard across all trims.

Variants and Prices:

 	B4: ₹7.99 lakh
 	B6: ₹8.69 lakh
 	B6(O): ₹9.09 lakh
 	B8: ₹9.69 lakh

New Bolero Neo

The Bolero Neo combines the Bolero’s ruggedness with modern styling and urban-focused features. It has a redesigned front grille with horizontal accents, dark metallic grey 16-inch alloy wheels, and new exterior colours, Jeans Blue and Concrete Grey, along with dual-tone options. Existing colours include Diamond White, Stealth Black, Pearl White, and Rocky Beige. 2025 Bolero Neo

Inside, the Neo features leatherette seat covers with improved ergonomics and dual-tone interior themes in Lunar Grey and Mocha Brown. The 22.8 cm touchscreen infotainment system supports Android Auto and Apple CarPlay, and includes a rear-view camera and USB-C charging.

Top variants like N11 add cruise control, electrically adjustable ORVMs, ISOFIX mounts, and a height-adjustable driver seat. RideFlo Tech with MTV-CL and Frequency Dependent Damping improves ride comfort and handling, and Multi-Terrain Technology is available on N10 and N10(O).

The Neo uses a 1.5-litre mHawk diesel engine producing 100 hp and 260 Nm, with a 5-speed manual gearbox and rear-wheel-drive layout.

Variants and Prices:
 	N4: ₹8.49 lakh
 	N8: ₹9.29 lakh
 	N10: ₹9.79 lakh
 	N10(O): ₹9.79 lakh
 	N11: ₹9.99 lakh

Launched in 2000, the Bolero has sold over 16 lakh units in India and remains popular for its ground clearance, ladder-frame chassis, seven-seat capacity, fuel efficiency, and durability.

According to the company, the refreshed Neo strengthens Mahindra’s urban SUV offering, while the classic Bolero continues to serve traditional buyers.

title: India to revise CGHS rates from October 13: What may change for hospitals and beneficiaries
content:
HomeIndia NewsHealthcare NewsIndia to revise CGHS rates from October 13: What may change for hospitals and beneficiariesCGHS offers cashless medical treatment to central government employees, pensioners, and their dependents.The government has approved a comprehensive revision of rates under the Central Government Health Scheme (CGHS), marking the first major overhaul in close to 15 years. The updated pricing, covering nearly 2,000 medical procedures, will come into effect on October 13.

CGHS offers cashless medical treatment to central government employees, pensioners, and their dependents.

The revised framework introduces a multidimensional pricing structure, with rates now linked to hospital accreditation status, facility type, city classification, and ward entitlement.

Under the new system, National Accreditation Board for Hospitals (NABH) or National Accreditation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories (NABL)-accredited hospitals will serve as the benchmark for base rates. Non-accredited hospitals will receive 15% lower reimbursements. Super-specialty hospitals will be eligible for 15% higher rates, while facilities in Tier-2 and Tier-3 cities will be compensated at 10–20% below metro-level pricing.

Hospitals had been seeking an upward revision for several years, arguing that package rates—unchanged since 2014—had failed to keep pace with medical inflation.

In several instances, healthcare providers had either delayed or declined cashless CGHS treatments due to viability concerns.

Analysts estimate that the revised schedule translates into an average increase of 25–30% across high-volume procedures, with super-specialty centres receiving an additional 15% premium over standard NABH-linked rates.

Listed healthcare chains such as Max Healthcare, Narayana Health, Yatharth Hospitals, and Fortis are among those with higher exposure to CGHS patients and are therefore expected to see financial gains.

Sector experts say the move is likely to strengthen cash flows for Tier-1 and super-specialty hospitals, although timely settlement of dues will remain critical as the revised structure is rolled out.

title: Harvest Moon 2025: Why it’s in October instead of September this year
content:
While the Harvest Moon typically appears in September, it can sometimes fall in early October. The timing depends not on the month itself, but on which full moon is closest to the autumn equinox.The Harvest Moon of 2025 will light up the skies tonight, October 6, marking one of the brightest and most beautiful full moons of the year. Interestingly, this year’s Harvest Moon is appearing in October, not September – a rare but completely natural occurrence. Here’s why it happens and what makes it special.

What Is the Harvest Moon?

The Harvest Moon is the name given to the full moon that occurs closest to the autumnal equinox, typically falling around September 22.

Centuries ago, this moon provided extra evening light to farmers harvesting their crops, helping them work later into the night. Over time, it became known as the Harvest Moon – a symbol of abundance and the changing of seasons.

Why is it in October in 2025?

While the Harvest Moon typically appears in September, it can sometimes fall in early October. The timing depends not on the month itself, but on which full moon is closest to the autumn equinox.

In 2025, the September full moon occurred on September 7, nearly two weeks before the equinox – too early to earn the title. The next full moon, on October 6, occurs just after the equinox, making it the closest one and officially the Harvest Moon of 2025.
This shift happens due to the Moon’s 29.5-day orbit and the slight variations in how its cycle aligns with the solar calendar each year. These natural adjustments occasionally push the Harvest Moon into October, as they did this year.

Historically, an October Harvest Moon is rare, and based on current lunar-solar cycle patterns, such October occurrences typically repeat every two to three years. The last time one occurred was in 2020, and astronomical forecasts suggest the next October Harvest Moon will be in 2028.

A Rare Supermoon Appearance

Adding to the excitement, tonight’s Harvest Moon is also a supermoon – meaning it occurs when the Moon is near its closest point to Earth in its orbit.

Due to this proximity, the Moon will appear larger and brighter than usual, glowing with a warm golden hue as it rises over the horizon. Stargazers can expect a breathtaking view shortly after sunset.

When and How to Watch the Harvest Moon Tonight

The Harvest Moon will rise around sunset on Monday, October 6, and stay visible through the night.

For the best viewing experience:
 	Look toward the eastern horizon just after sunset.
 	Choose a clear, open area away from artificial lights.
 	The Moon will appear especially golden or orange when it is low in the sky, gradually becoming brighter as it rises higher.

Viewers across India, Europe, and North America should have excellent visibility, weather permitting.(Edited by : Priyanka Deshpande)

title: Bihar Elections 2025: CM Nitish Kumar inaugurates Patna Metro first phase; check route, stations, fare
content:
HomeIndia NewsPolitics NewsBihar Elections 2025: CM Nitish Kumar inaugurates Patna Metro first phase; check route, stations, fareThe metro service runs daily from 8 am to 10 pm, with 40 to 42 trips scheduled along the corridor.Weeks ahead of the upcoming assembly elections in the state, Bihar Chief Minister Nitish Kumar on Monday, October 6, inaugurated the first phase of the Patna Metro Rail Project. This initial phase of the 3.6-km elevated stretch of the Blue Line will open to the public on October 7, 2025.

With an aim to ease the city's traffic congestion, the inaugural stretch of the priority corridor will run from the Inter-State Bus Terminal (ISBT) to Bhoothnath station. It will cover three key stations — Patliputra ISBT, Zero Mile, and Bhoothnath.
#WATCH | Patna: Bihar Chief Minister Nitish Kumar today inaugurated the first phase of the 3.6-km elevated stretch of the priority corridor of the Patna Metro rail project
The inaugural stretch on the Blue Line will run from the Inter-State Bus Terminal (ISBT) to Bhoothnath pic.twitter.com/QiiBoNJy82

— ANI (@ANI) October 6, 2025
The inaugural run of the metro was conducted from the Patliputra Bus Depot. Deputy Chief Ministers Samrat Choudhary and Vijay Kumar Sinha were also present at the ceremony. In February 2019, Prime Minister Narendra Modi laid the foundation stone for the metro project, estimated to cost ₹ 13,365 crores.

Hailing the project earlier in the day, Bihar BJP President Dilip Jaiswal said that the people will be relieved of traffic jams. In a conversation with ANI, he said, “Today will be written in golden letters in the history of Patna that the people of Patna, the people of Bihar, are getting the facility of Metro Rail. Until now, we used to go to Kolkata and Delhi to see the Metro Rail. People will be relieved of the problem of traffic jams.”

JD(U) leader Rajiv Ranjan Prasad also lauded the project, saying CM Nitish Kumar has taken ‘big decisions’ for the state. “The long wait of the people of Patna is about to end. Under the leadership of Chief Minister Nitish Kumar, undoubtedly, big decisions have been taken for the state,” Prasad added.

Route and stations

The first operational route covers an approximately 4.3-km stretch. The route runs from the Inter-State Bus Terminal (ISBT) to Bhoothnath. The three main stations on this stretch are: Patliputra ISBT, Zero Mile and Bhoothnath.

Timings

The metro service runs daily from 8 am to 10 pm, with 40 to 42 trips scheduled along the corridor. In the initial phase, trains are scheduled to run every 20 minutes.

Fare

The fare structure is based on the number of stations travelled. The minimum fare is ₹15 for a single station ride, while the maximum fare is ₹30 for the full route between ISBT and Bhoothnath.

Facilities

The coaches are designed with motifs inspired by Bihar’s famous Madhubani art, featuring traditional patterns. Each train has a seating capacity of 158 passengers, with 12 seats reserved for women and differently-abled individuals.

Additionally, each train has standing space for up to 940.

The coaches have modern amenities like charging points for cellphones and laptops, front emergency doors and bi-parting sliding doors for enhanced safety and passenger experience.(Edited by : Sudarsanan Mani)First Published: Oct 6, 2025 1:55 PM IST

title: Maserati MCPura launched in India with Coupe and Cielo variants
content: Maserati has launched the MCPura supercar in India, offering Coupe and Cielo variants with a 3.0L V6 engine, top speed of 325 km/h, and prices starting at ₹4.12 crore.1 / 7Maserati Debuts: Italian automaker Maserati recently launched the MC Pura in India. The supercar is available in two variants: the hardtop Coupe and the open-roof Cielo. The Coupe starts at ₹4.12 crore, while the Cielo is priced at Rs 5.12 crore (ex-showroom). Both models are powered by a 3.0-litre twin-turbo V6 engine and are mechanically identical to their international counterparts.2 / 7Design Updates: The MC Pura retains the MC20 silhouette but features design updates. The grille has a dark surround, and the front splitter is modified. Air intakes below the headlamps are larger. At the rear, the bumper has subtle refinements. Maserati worked with Dallara to enhance the car’s aerodynamic efficiency. The coupe has a matte finish, while the convertible has a glossy finish.3 / 7Signature Badging: Exterior branding receives a visual update. The Trident emblems on the grille and C-pillar, MCPura lettering on the flanks, and wheel center caps feature magenta with blue mica particles. Glossy finishes appear on the coupe, while matte finishes highlight the Cielo. The badges contrast against the body paint, giving the supercars a distinct visual identity compared to the MC20.4 / 7Engine Performance: Both variants use the 3.0-litre twin-turbocharged Nettuno V6, producing 621 horsepower and 719–730 Nm of torque. Power is sent to the rear wheels via an eight-speed dual-clutch automatic gearbox. The Coupe accelerates from 0–100 km/h in 2.9 seconds, while the Cielo does it in 3.0 seconds. Both reach a top speed of 325 km/h.5 / 7Interior Features: The MCPura cabin follows the MC20 layout with new touches. Seats feature laser-etched Alcantara with vertical striping and contrasting red and blue tones. The dashboard has a digital instrument cluster, central touchscreen, and three-spoke steering wheel with engine start/stop and shift paddles. Carbon fibre trims line the cabin. The Cielo has matte detailing, while the Coupe features glossy interior accents.6 / 7Maserati MCPura7 / 7Model Evolution: The MCPura replaces the MC20 in India. Its global debut occurred at the Goodwood Festival of Speed earlier this year. The MCPura is an evolution of the MC20 with subtle styling changes and a refreshed paint palette. Mechanically, both models remain unchanged. The Cielo convertible is priced ₹19 lakh lower than the MC20 Cielo available in India since May.

title: Lawyer tries to attack CJI in Supreme Court alleging insult to Sanatan Dharma, Gavai says 'not distracted'

The lawyer allegedly tried to remove his shoe and throw it at CJI Gavai after he went near the dais, reported Bar and Bench, citing sources.

His identity is not confirmed yet.

His attempt to attack the CJI was reportedly stopped by the security officials present in the court, who intervened quickly and escorted him out.

"Sanatan ka apman nahi sahenge (Will not tolerate the insult of Sanatan Dharma)," the lawyer said, as per Bar and Bench, when he was being escorted out of the room.

CJI Gavai, however, remained calm and proceeded to ask the lawyers to continue with their cases and arguments.

"Don't get distracted by all this. We are not distracted. These things do not affect me," Justice Gavai was quoted as saying by Bar and Bench.
The incident was possibly linked with CJI Gavai's earlier remarks in a case related to the restoration of the Lord Vishnu idol at the Khajuraho group of temples.

"Go and ask the deity itself to do something now. You say you are a staunch devotee of Lord Vishnu. So go and pray now. It’s an archaeological site and ASI needs to give permission etc," CJI Gavai had reportedly remarked while dismissing the plea, as per B&B.

His remarks, however, led to a controversy on social media after the remarks were widely shared, alleging that the statement hurt religious sentiments.

Later, the CJI had clarified that he respects all religions and did not mean to hurt the sentiments of any community. "I respect all religions," CJI Gavai had said.

The Supreme Court's security unit initiated an inquiry into the attack incident, as per a news agency PTI.

Former secretary of the Supreme Court Bar Association, Advocate Rohit Pandey criticised the act and called for action in the case. "Today's incident is a very sad one. If a lawyer has committed or attempted to commit assault in a court, we strongly condemn it. He is a member of our bar. We recently inquired and found out that he is a member of the 2011 Bar. But it is a very sad incident," Pandey told news agency ANI.

"He (the lawyer) attempted this based on the comment made by the CJI in the case of a Lord Vishnu matter. This is a very sad incident. We strongly condemn this, and if this incident is true, action should be taken," he added.

Further details are awaited in the matter.First Published: Oct 6, 2025 1:24 PM IST

title: First supermoon of 2025 rises tonight: All you need to know
content:
NASA said the supermoon will dominate the sky on Monday, October 6, the night the Draconid meteor shower is expected to start.The first supermoon of 2025 will be visible to skywatchers worldwide on the night of October 6 as the Harvest Moon reaches its closest and fullest point, appearing up to 30% brighter and 14% bigger than a normal full moon.

This particular lunar spectacle expands as the Harvest Moon — the full moon that falls closest to the autumnal equinox (this year on September 22) — a traditional marker in various cultures for the harvesting season.

According to NASA, the supermoon will dominate the sky on October 6, the night the Draconid meteor shower is expected to start. However, the Harvest Moon in October might be too bright for people to appreciate the meteor shower completely.

Timing and Viewing Tips

The Harvest Supermoon will rise in the eastern sky on Monday, October 6, at 6:55 pm ET and set at 8:05 am ET the following day. Additionally, the moon will be full when it rises at 7:28 pm ET on Tuesday.

The full moon is predicted to achieve its maximum brightness around 11:48 pm ET on October 6 (early October 7 in UTC). Beginning on the evening of October 5 and continuing through October 7, the moon will be nearly full in many locations.

Experts advise viewing the Moon shortly after moonrise or close to moonset, when it is low on the horizon and its shape looks exaggerated due to an atmospheric phenomenon called the ‘moon illusion,’ for the most dramatic views.

Look for a spot with an open view; fields, parks, and waterfronts are excellent spots to observe the scenery.

It is advised to use a tripod for photography. Consider adding foreground objects (trees, buildings) to provide a sense of scale, and use slower exposures to prevent overexposure of the bright lunar disc.

Why It Happens

A ‘supermoon’ happens when the moon is both full and close to perigee, the point in its elliptical orbit that comes closest to Earth. Although the change is barely noticeable for many casual observers, the moon may appear substantially bigger and brighter than usual due to its proximity.

The moon will come close to Earth during the most recent viewing, approximately 224,600 miles (361,459 km) away. Three supermoons in 2025 will follow after this one, with the following two being on November 5 (Beaver Supermoon) and December 4 (Cold Moon Supermoon).

Two lunar eclipses will occur in 2026: A total eclipse in March that will be visible from most of North America, Asia, and Australia, and a partial eclipse in August that will be visible from the Americas, Africa, and Europe.(Edited by : Sudarsanan Mani)

title: Delhi horror: Raped, blackmailed for weeks, 18-year-old MBBS student finally reports to police
content:
HomeIndia NewsDelhi horror: Raped, blackmailed for weeks, 18-year-old MBBS student finally reports to policeThe student is originally from Jind, Haryana, and lives in the Dr Baba Saheb Ambedkar Medical College hostel in Adarsh Nagar.An 18-year-old MBBS student was allegedly raped and drugged by a 20-year-old man and two of his friends at a hotel in Northwest Delhi's Adarsh Nagar. The incident took place in September 2025, but the case was registered on Friday, October 3, 2025, after the victim reported it to the police.

The student is reportedly originally from Jind, Haryana, and lives in the Dr Baba Saheb Ambedkar Medical College hostel in Adarsh Nagar, while the accused has been identified as Amanpreet.

According to the medical student, the accused invited her to a hotel on the pretext of a party, where he allegedly raped her, took obscene photos and videos, and threatened to make the footage public. At the hotel, her drink was reportedly spiked. After she was incapacitated, the main accused allegedly raped her while his two friends filmed the act and later sexually assaulted her.

Following the initial assault, the accused allegedly used the filmed footage to blackmail the student and force her into repeated encounters for nearly a month.

“She told us that after the September incident, he used the video to blackmail her into multiple subsequent assaults throughout September, threatening to share the footage on social media if she refused,” the police said, as reported by the Hindustan Times.
Police filed a case on Friday and are looking for the suspects, all of whom are currently at large, according to Deputy Commissioner of Police (northwest) Bhisham Singh.

A senior police officer familiar with the matter stated that the victim approached authorities on Thursday. In her complaint, she mentioned that the accused was also from Jind and preparing for competitive exams in North Delhi. On September 9, he invited her to a hotel room party along with two friends.

“She said that she knew the accused as he hails from Jind, where the two lived in the same neighbourhood,” according to the officer, who asked not to be identified.

The victim eventually confided in her family, who supported her in approaching the police to file a complaint. A case was registered under section 64(1) of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (punishment for rape).

“The woman was counselled, and her statement before the magistrate is to be registered. Multiple teams are looking for the accused,” the officer added.

In a similar case reported in August, a 24-year-old woman was alleged to have been gang raped by four men at a party in north Delhi's Civil Lines.

The victim had alleged that a male friend had invited her to a party at a friend’s house, where the accused spiked her drinks and raped her.(Edited by : Sudarsanan Mani)

title: Bihar Election Date 2025 Highlights: Voting on Nov 6 and 11, ECINET app to streamline 40 services
content:
Political parties have urged the poll body to hold the polls immediately after the Chhath festival, which will be celebrated at the end of October, to ensure greater voter participation as a large number of people employed outside return home for festivities.(Photo Credit : Bihar Elections 2025 scheduled announced (Photo: X/@ECISVEEP))The Bihar Assembly election will be held in two phases on November 6 and 11, announced Election Commission on Monday (October 6). The result will be announced on November 14.

The term of the 243-member state assembly ends on November 22.

Over 7.4 crore people will exercise their franchise, including 14 lakh first-time voters, Chief Election Commissioner (CEC) Gyanesh Kumar announced. "There are a total of 7.42 crore voters in Bihar, of which 3.92 crore are males and 3.5 crore are women. There are 14 lakh first-time voters and 4 lakh senior citizen voters," Kumar said.

Political parties have urged the poll body to hold the polls immediately after the Chhath festival, which will be celebrated at the end of October, to ensure greater voter participation as a large number of people employed outside return home for festivities.

The 2020 Assembly polls in the state were held in three phases under the shadow of the COVID-19 pandemic.

More than 500 companies of the Central Armed Police Forces (CAPFs), comprising over 5,000 personnel, will be deployed for the Bihar elections. Of these, 121 companies are from the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) and around 400 from the Border Security Force (BSF), along with contingents from other CAPFs, ANI quoted sources.

title: Darjeeling landslides: Death toll rises to 28, CM announces ₹5 lakh compensation for victims' families
content:
HomeIndia NewsEnvironment NewsDarjeeling landslides: Death toll rises to 28, CM announces ₹5 lakh compensation for victims' familiesThe district was battered by over 300 mm of rain in just 12 hours, which triggered landslides and ravaged the Darjeeling hills and the Dooars region at the foothills.The death toll in the landslides in the Darjeeling district of West Bengal rose to 28. Several people were missing, and thousands of tourists were stranded in the hill station, as disaster management personnel continued the rescue operation on Monday (October 6).

Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee announced ₹5 lakh compensation for the victims' families.

"The situation remains extremely challenging. Several people are still missing, and the toll is likely to go up. Continuous rainfall is hampering the rescue operations," North Bengal Development Minister Udayan Guha told PTI.

The district was battered by over 300 mm of rain in just 12 hours, which triggered landslides and ravaged the Darjeeling hills and the Dooars region at the foothills.
#WATCH | Darjeeling, West Bengal | A portion of the Dudhia iron bridge collapsed due to heavy rain in North Bengal. pic.twitter.com/2TBFQiDMtK
— ANI (@ANI) October 6, 2025


Mirik, Sukhiapokhri, and Jorebunglow in Darjeeling, and Nagrakata in Jalpaiguri district were among the worst-affected areas.

Manoj Rai, a villager affected by the landslide in Darjeeling, said, "There is a pile of mud and stones in my house. I request the government to make a home for us."

Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee is scheduled to visit the affected areas later in the day.

The district administration has set up relief camps in coordination with the Gorkhaland Territorial Administration (GTA) and local NGOs, an official said.

"Food, blankets, medicines, and drinking water are being provided to all displaced families," he said.

GTA Executive Member Arun Sigchi told ANI, "It was a very heavy rainfall of about 200mm. There have been 11 casualties in Mirik. A total of 18 casualties have been officially reported in Darjeeling. The Dudhia Bridge has been totally damaged. There has been a lot of loss. Rangbhang Valley is totally damaged. We do not have any missing reports at this time. Relief camps are going on. I request that the state and central governments declare this a national disaster. The government should provide all kinds of support."First Published: Oct 6, 2025 12:40 PM IST

title: Cyclone Shakhti: Storm likely to weaken into a depression on October 7
content:
The cyclone is expected to move east-southeast wards and weaken into a depression by the morning of October 7.Cyclone Shakti, the first post-monsoon cyclonic storm in the Arabian Sea, has weakened from ‘severe’ to a cyclonic storm. As of 05:30 am on October 6, it was centred over the west-central and adjoining northwest Arabian Sea, near latitude 19.6°N and longitude 60.4°E.

It moved nearly southwards at a speed of 5 kmph during the past few hours, according to the India Meteorological Department (IMD). The cyclone is expected to move east-southeastward and weaken into a depression by the morning of October 7.

The storm is located approximately 200 km southeast of Masirah (Oman), 310 km south-southeast of Ras Al Hadd (Oman), 910 km southwest of Karachi (Pakistan), 950 km west-southwest of Dwarka and 970 km west-southwest of Naliya.
The severe #cyclonic #storm #Shakhti over westcentral and adjoining northwest Arabian Sea movednearly southwards with a speed of 5 kmph during last 6 hours, weakened into a #Cyclonic Storm and lay centered at 0530 hrs IST of today, the 6th October,2025 over the same region. pic.twitter.com/KAWe3Ik4mB
— India Meteorological Department (@Indiametdept) October 6, 2025

The cyclone has caused heavy rainfall in several parts of the country over the past few days. The Met Office has issued a warning for the cyclone in many parts of Maharashtra, including Mumbai, Thane, Palghar, Raigad, Ratnagiri, and Sindhudurg, with strong winds expected till October 7.
IMD scientist Sushma Nair stated on Saturday that “no threat of cyclone to the Maharashtra coast” exists, with just mild to moderate rainfall forecast in Mumbai and surrounding areas this week.

On Monday, October 6, the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) issued a tidal forecast for Mumbai, predicting a high tide in the Arabian Sea owing to Cyclone 'Shakti'. The public is urged not to go into the water or beaches since the highest waves are expected today, reaching up to 4.5 meters.

title: Op Sindoor damaged F-16s, AWACS and radars in Pakistan, US stepped in for repairs
content:
HomeIndia NewsOp Sindoor damaged F-16s, AWACS and radars in Pakistan, US stepped in for repairsUS sent special teams on Asim Munir’s request but reportedly blocked China from assisting in repairs over concerns of technology theft, particularly related to the F-16s and C-130From damaged F-16s and Swedish-made AWACS aircraft to shattered radar systems and command centres—India’s Operation Sindoor severely crippled multiple Pakistani Air Force bases in May this year, leaving the country scrambling for urgent repairs, exclusive documents and high-level confirmations accessed by CNN-News18 have revealed.The revelations of the damage caused by the air strike, which flattened terrorist havens in Pakistan and PoK on May 9-10 in the aftermath of the Pahalgam terror attack, fly in the face of the neighbour’s assertion that none of its aircraft were hit or destroyed.
CNN-News18 has learnt that the Indian strike damaged critical Pakistani military infrastructure, including a Swedish-made Saab 2000 Erieye AWACS, a Lockheed C-130, and at least four F-16 fighter jets. Several radar systems, command and control units, and air defence installations were also hit in targeted missile strikes across multiple airbases.
One of the most significant hits occurred at PAF Bholari Airbase, where an F-16 jet parked in a hangar was destroyed, resulting in the death of five PAF personnel, including a Squadron Leader and Chief Technician. The AWACS Erieye, also hit at Bholari, was later repaired by US Air Force engineers flown in urgently.
Further damage was reported at:
PAF Shahbaz Air Base (Jacobabad) – Two F-16s destroyed in hangars
Nur Khan Airbase (Rawalpindi) – One F-16 and a C-130 hit in a precision strike
Sarghodha, Rahim Yar Khan, and Mushaf Airbase – Infrastructure like runways, hangars, and communication systems severely damaged.
High-level Pakistani defence sources revealed that $400–$470 million in secret emergency funds were approved in late May for repairs and upgrades. The United States reportedly blocked China from assisting in the repairs over concerns of technology theft, particularly related to the F-16s and C-130 aircraft.
To expedite repairs, the US dispatched special teams from Al-Udeid Airbase (Doha), Al Dhafra (Abu Dhabi), and Bethesda (Maryland) after Field Marshal Asim Munir personally requested help during meetings with US President Donald Trump and retired CENTCOM Chief Michael Kurilla.
Multiple US military flights (C-17s and C-130s) were tracked landing at Nur Khan Airbase between June and September, confirming covert US activity on Pakistani soil. The US support was further acknowledged when Pakistan awarded General Kurilla its highest military honour in July 2025.
While most damage has now been repaired, sources indicate Rahim Yar Khan’s airbase runway remains out of service due to ongoing flooding in South Punjab. PAF is also fast-tracking upgrades with a hybrid American-Chinese satellite-integrated radar system, intended to prevent future vulnerabilities.
The revelation underscores the scale, precision, and aftermath of Operation Sindoor, which inflicted strategic damage to Pakistan’s air capabilities and revealed Islamabad’s growing reliance on US military assistance despite rising Chinese collaboration.

title: Supreme Court issues notice to Centre, Ladakh UT on Sonam Wangchuk's wife's plea challenging detention

However, a bench of Justices Aravind Kumar and NV Anjaria refused to pass any order on providing grounds of detention to Wangchuk's wife and posted the matter for hearing on October 14.

Wangchuk was detained under the stringent National Security Act (NSA) on September 26, two days after protests demanding statehood and Sixth Schedule status for Ladakh left four people dead and 90 injured in the Union territory.
